awd_titl_txt: Conference on Establishing an Evidence-Based Approach to Understanding and Countering Mass Violence
awd_abstract_narration:
Mass violence has become a common occurrence in the United States. Mass violence takes many forms: family massacres, terrorist attacks, shootings related to other crimes (like robbery), gang violence, and other incidents in which offenders attack targeted individuals and/or random strangers. The phenomenon of indiscriminate mass public violence, often directed at strangers, particularly has generated the most public alarm in recent years. Mass public attacks appear to have increased in regularity and severity, leading to a heightened sense of national fear in our communities, schools and colleges, and so on. While such events are seemingly random, they are likely not, and therefore possibly preventable in many instances. Indeed, these events are linked by numerous themes: mental illness, domestic violence, grudges, bigotry, political polarization, copycat behaviors, and the rise and more open behavior of fringe groups, to name a few. Mass violence has become an urgent problem that needs an updated and contemporary research evidence-base, translation activities to turn that research into effective interventions, and improved social services to ensure the interventions are implemented well. 

The goals of the two day conference will be to: 1) review research that has been conducted on mass violence; 2) determine points of consensus in the available research; 3) identify gaps in research knowledge and points of substantial disagreement; 4) identify policy implications stemming from established research knowledge; and 5) develop research recommendations to address knowledge gaps and controversies in the field.  Following the conference, findings will be communicated to researchers and policy makers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mass violence has become an all too common occurrence in the United States. During the last decade alone, thousands have been killed or injured in acts of mass violence committed with firearms and other means. Mass public attacks, in particular, appear to have increased in regularity and severity, leading to a heightened sense of national fear. Addressing this urgent problem requires an updated and contemporary research evidence-base, translation activities to turn that research into effective interventions, and improved social services to ensure interventions are implemented well. To meet this national need, George Mason University and Carnegie Mellon University organized a NSF workshop on April 11-12, 2019, to advance an evidence-based approach to understanding and countering domestic mass violence in the U.S.

The workshop brought together diverse experts from a variety of fields (e.g., criminology, psychology, statistics, economics, public health) and sectors (i.e., academic, government, and non-profit) who provided broad knowledge and perspective on this issue. The project addressed several aspects of mass violence, including patterns and trends; data and measurement challenges; etiology; settings; weaponry access; threat assessment and prevention; the role of social media; and strengthening emergency responses. The workshop's goals included reviewing research that has been conducted on mass violence; determining points of consensus in the research; identifying gaps in research knowledge and points of substantial disagreement; identifying policy implications stemming from established research knowledge; and developing research recommendations to address knowledge gaps and controversies in the field.

The primary outputs of this workshop are 16 papers that will appear in the February 2020 (Volume 19, Issue 1) journal of Criminology & Public Policy, the policy journal of the American Society of Criminology. Each paper can be downloaded before February 2020 from the Early View section of the journal, located at https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/17459133. They appear below in alphabetical order of the first author, with the policy recommendations overview listed first:

1. Daniel S. Nagin, Christopher S. Koper, and Cynthia Lum. Policy Recommendations for Countering Mass Shootings in the United States.

2. Richard Berk and Susan Sorenson. Algorithmic Approach to Forecasting Rare Violent Events: An Illustration Based in Intimate Partner Violence Perpetration.

3. Dewey Cornell. Threat Assessment as a School Violence Prevention Strategy.

4. Arie Croitoru, Sarah Kien, Ron Mahabir, Jacek Radzikowski, Andrew Crooks, Ross Schuchard, Tatyanna Begay, Ashley Lee, Alex Bettios, and Anthony Stefanidis. Responses to Mass Shooting Events: The Interplay between the Media and the Public.

5. Grant Duwe. Patterns and Prevalence of Lethal Mass Violence.

6. Joshua Freilich, Steven Chermak, and Brent Klein. Investigating the Applicability of Situational Crime Prevention to the Public Mass Violence Context.

7. Lin Huff-Corzine and Jay Corzine. The Devil?s in the Details: Measuring Mass Violence.

8. Christopher S. Koper. Assessing the Potential to Reduce Deaths and Injuries from Mass Shootings through Restrictions on Assault Weapons and Other High-Capacity Semiautomatic Firearms.

9. Peter Langman. Desperate Identities: A Bio-Psycho-Social Analysis of Perpetrators of Mass Violence.

10. Adam Lankford and James Silver. Why Have Public Mass Shootings Become More Deadly? Assessing How Perpetrators? Motives and Methods Have Changed Over Time.

11. Hannah Laqueur and Garen J. Wintemute. Identifying High-Risk Firearm Owners to Prevent Mass Violence.

12. Paul Reeping, Sara Jacoby, Sonali Rajan, and Charles Branas. Rapid Response to Mass Shootings: A Review and Recommendations.

13. James Silver. The Space between Concern and Crime: Two Recommendations for Promoting the Adoption of the Threat Assessment Model and Encouraging Bystander Reporting.

14. Jennifer Skeem and Edward Mulvey. What Role Does Serious Mental Illness Play in Mass Shootings, and How Should We Address It?

15. Daniel Webster, Alexander McCourt, Cassandra Crifasi, and Marisa Booty. Evidence Concerning the Regulation of Firearms Design, Sale, and Carrying on Fatal Mass Shootings in the United States.

16. April Zeoli and Jennifer Paruk. Potential to Prevent Mass Shootings through Domestic Violence Firearm Restrictions.

Based on the workshop papers and discussions, the principal investigators made five policy and research recommendations that are summarized in the Nagin, Koper, and Lum article listed above. These recommendations include: (1) staunching the growth of high capacity firearms; (2) curtailing access to firearms for individuals who are a danger to others or themselves; (3) improving threat detection systems; (4) strengthening emergency responses to mass shooting events; and (5) improving data collection infrastructures to formally track mass violence incidents.

This workshop also resulted in two additional dissemination and translation activities in 2019. The first, organized and supported by the Center for Evidence-Based Crime Policy (CEBCP) at George Mason University, included a featured panel on mass violence at the CEBCP 2019 Annual Symposium (June 2019). The agenda for the CEBCP 2019 Symposium is located here: https://cebcp.org/cebcp-symposium-2019/. The second was a Congressional briefing organized at the U.S. Capitol in September 2019 by the CEBCP with additional funding from the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation. The agenda and videos for that briefing are located here: https://cebcp.org/outreach-symposia-and-briefings/mass-violence/.
